On Wed, 30 Mar 2005 20:10:31 -0000, gerbopel <redcrocodile@...> wrote:
>
> The reason I'm asking all these questions is that I am trying to
> evolve my agents on a particular task at the moment and it is just not
> getting there.  If I evolve them for 1000 generations, it just won't
> get there.  It got the solution once but I've since added another
> input so the previous genome is invalid to the project.

Okay.  At this point I'd like to ask a couple of questions.  What do
your fitness curves look like?  Is the population improving at all? 
Is it gradual or spiky?

Thanks for explaining your domain a bit more.  In an earlier mail you
said you had some success with XOR and "several other tests that
actually relate to my
project".  What were those?  Were they similar implementations of this
domain that simply had smaller mazes?

> If he sees the mouse he can catch it just
> fine but as soon as the mouse goes out of view, it collapses.  I've
> used incremental learning to teach one thing at a time but when I
> setup the out-of-sight mouse experiment, it just won't converge.

At this point I'd kind of like a visualization of the maze.  I'm
having a bit of a hard time understanding what's going on here.  Have
you done any crude animations to visualize the behavior here?  Could
you post a BMP of what a sample maze looks like?

By "collapse", what do you mean?  What are the starting conditions? 
Do the cat and mouse start out in random positions in the maze?  Do
they always have a forward velocity, and the neural network outputs
only control left or right turns at intersections?  You say as long as
it "sees the mouse" it can catch it.  So presumably there's an input
for whether or not the mouse is in line-of-sight, correct?  What are
the other inputs?

I guess my initial reaction is that since the algorithm has worked on
other tasks, the first place to look might be the domain
implementation.

It could also be that your fitness gradient is too steep.  For
example, we had very good success evolving active vision (or a roving
eye) controlled by an evolved neural network, that roams across a
black and white 2d surface and recognizes simple shapes (squares,
triangles, etc.).  We also did a few experiments with sans-serif
letters that worked reasonably well.  When we made the jump to
fingerprint classification, we were able to evolve networks that could
only distinguish between a handful of prints.  Anything approaching a
medium to large database and so far our system has hit a wall.

Now there are tons of variables, both algorithm-specific and
domain-specific, that can be adjusted.  But sometimes the domain is
just really, really hard.  Our own approach is to scale back to
shapes, and incrementally increase the difficulty of the domain by
adding in additional noise (pixel noise, decreased contrast) to see
where we hit that wall and try to isolate the variables we need to
tweak to get over those humps.

It's hard, but it's also interesting. :)  I'd like to know more about
your specific domain, and maybe others on the list will have thoughts
about what might need to be changed where to achieve success.

Derek
